title: 'Last Night in Soho': Garbled but Good Looking
summary: Cinematography is the star of Edgar Wright's latest, a time-travel tale that takes a young fashion student back to 1960s London, then lurches into a timeworn realm. I was glad to go along with Edgar Wright as "Last Night in Soho" got under way, and why not? He's the man who gave zombies and robots new leases on life in his classic comedy-horror trilogy comprised of "Shaun Of the Dead," "Hot Fuzz" and "The World's End."

title: The Facts on Trump's Fraud Letter

And we think it's news when an ex-President who may run in 2024 wrote what he did, even if (or perhaps especially if) his claims are bananas.

title: Fed Tapering Won't Beat Inflation
summary: Supply issues are mostly to blame for rising prices. Deregulation is a crucial part of the remedy.. Many expect the Fed will reduce bond purchases by $15 billion a month starting in November.

title: The Obsolete Science Behind Roe v. Wade
summary: My youngest patients are unborn babies, and today's ultrasounds show they are fully alive and human.. The Supreme Court will soon reconsider the decision in Roe v. Wade (1973), which made abortion legal in America through all nine months of pregnancy. At that "point in the development of man's knowledge," as Justice Harry Blackmun put it in Roe, there was simply no consensus about when life begins. In other words, the fetus could not be said with any certainty to be alive and therefore wasn't worthy of legal protection.

title: 'Games People Played' Review: The Agony and the Ecstasy
summary: For many people, sports go far beyond mere fun and enjoyment. The results can be a source of both deep pride and utter disappointment.. Sports would count for nothing without history. Tradition is the only thing that raises athletics above idle pastime. Tiger Woods may be good at hitting a tiny ball into a little hole, but his significance to the game is measured by the long line of golfing heroes before him, stretching back past Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer, through Walter Hagen and Bobby Jones, all the way to Young and Old Tom Morris in Scotland in the late 19th century. In boxing, we not only have the official title holder, but also the lineal champion-the man who beat the man who beat the man, going back to the first undisputed conquerors of the sport. The point applies across the board. The achievements of today's star athletes are given meaning by our memories of their predecessors.

title: Drilling in Yellowstone Could Save America
summary: A plan for generating carbon-free energy and staving off a caldera explosion.. It's not often that nature provides a win-win for it and humanity, but the caldera system under Yellowstone National Park is certainly one. If harnessed, it could power much of America for generations. Ignoring it means a guaranteed eruption and the destruction of a great portion of the U.S. and Canada.

title: Where Did the 'N' in 'NGO' Go?
summary: 'Nongovernmental organizations' in the Palestinian territories toe the authorities' line.. What does the N in NGO stand for? summary: Clinton and Obama both overcame adversity, but the 46th president doesn't have their political gifts.. In a way Republicans have already won in Virginia. If Mr. McAuliffe pulls it out Tuesday, his not-so-Trumpy challenger, Glenn Youngkin, will still have come close in the age of Trump, and his campaign will have provided a rough pathway for how future party candidates can make their way through: 1. Be a respectable, capable-seeming person who focuses on legitimate local issues (schools, taxes.) 2. Don't say crazy things. 3. Don't insult Donald Trump but do everything to keep him away.

title: 'The Souvenir: Part II': The Past Spun Into Gold
summary: The sequel to Joanna Hogg's semi-autobiographical 2019 feature picks up the story of a film student trying to overcome heartbreak while creating her graduation project. 'The Souvenir: Part II" is Joanna Hogg's sequel to her semi-autobiographical 2019 feature "The Souvenir," which starred Honor Swinton Byrne as Julie, a film-school student in 1980s England. Sequels are unusual in independent film-no superheroes available for marketing-but this one represented a twofold risk. How do you follow a film that seemed perfect in itself, a model of compression and self-containment about a ravaging love affair and the growing pains of a young artist at a pivot point in her life? The answer, playing in select theaters, turns out to be daringly intricate and beautifully simple. Ms. Hogg has outdone herself with an even stronger film about grief, self-discovery, the daunting uncertainties of the creative process and, before and after everything else, the mysterious power of the movie medium.

title: The Mexican Government Replies to O'Grady on Energy
summary: Active contracts for electricity will be reviewed in accordance with the law.. Nothing could be further from the truth: Mexico's relationship with the U.S. is an excellent one at this time. We are updating our mechanisms of cooperation in various areas to reflect the enormous complexity of the relations between our two countries, as both partners and neighbors.

title: A Statutory Path for Yellen's Global Tax Treaty
summary: The World Trade Organization was approved by Congress in 1994 using only a statute.. Using a statute to approve and implement this treaty is hardly a "legislative ploy," and the statutory method would not be questionable in other countries as to whether it is a "proper treaty."

title: Why Beef Wellington Is the Smart Move This Holiday Season
summary: This showstopper dish is easier to pull off than you think. Prep it a day ahead and just pop it in the oven before the festive meal. Use these pro tips and accessible recipes for turkey, beef and vegan variations.. A CLASSIC Wellington-beef tenderloin smothered in a paté-enhanced mushroom duxelles, baked within a pastry crust-is a dish I've always treasured at the table and found elusive in the kitchen. The first time I ventured to make it, I found out why the Wellington is usually reserved for special occasions: Laborious and tricky, the recipe is a minefield of kitchen disasters waiting to happen. If all goes well, expect a juicy, crisp-crusted, richly flavored centerpiece to a festive meal with a tremendous wow factor. If not, you're left with a soggy log encircling bland, dried-out meat-after a day toiling in the kitchen.

Since then, the Jack Dorsey-led company has added more services for businesses, a digital-payments service for consumers known as Cash App, a payments platform for artists and a developer platform that plans to build a decentralized bitcoin exchange.

title: The Radicalism of James Madison
summary: The Father of the Constitution took extraordinary steps to sweep away America's first, dysfunctional form of government. James Madison is remembered today as the "Father of the Constitution" for his central role in framing a new government in the crucial early years of the republic. Yet the title inadvertently renders him a defender of today's status quo. His memory is invoked to rebut any criticism of the Constitution, which makes Madison appear much more conventional than he was. In fact, his vision for a national republic was a bold challenge to the established order. He also was pragmatic, cunning, and skilled in the art of politics. It was through this unique blend of theoretical and practical wisdom that Madison helped to overturn the old order and replace it with a daring alternative. More than two centuries later, he provides an example worth studying as we face our own constitutional quandaries.

title: Activision Chief Reduces Pay, Pledges Changes Amid Culture Probes
summary: Bobby Kotick says videogame publisher will end mandatory arbitration for sexual-harassment, discrimination claims. Bobby Kotick, the longtime chief executive of videogame publisher Activision Blizzard Inc., told employees Thursday he would take a pay cut and end mandatory arbitration for internal harassment and discrimination claims amid regulatory probes into the company's culture.

title: Hamptons Home of Macklowe Gallery Founders Lists for $60 Million
summary: The East Hampton house has ocean and Georgica Pond views.. For nearly 30 years, art and antique dealers Barbara and Lloyd Macklowe filled their East Hampton home with rare furniture, sculptures and paintings.

title: WPP Raises Its Revenue Outlook After Third-Quarter Growth
summary: The company reported like-for-like net revenue growth of 15.7% in the quarter as clients continued to boost spending. Advertising giant WPP PLC raised its guidance for revenue growth this year after its clients continued to invest in marketing in the third quarter and like-for-like net revenue in the period increased 15.7% compared with 2020, the company said.

title: T. Rowe Price to Buy Debt-Investment Firm Oak Hill Advisors in $4.2 Billion Deal
summary: Many money managers have recently made acquisitions to help their bottom line with new products or scale. Money manager T. Rowe Price Group Inc. agreed to buy Oak Hill Advisors for as much as $4.2 billion to enter the private-debt investing business.

title: America Has Supply-Side Problems
summary: Consumers and businesses alike are having trouble acquiring the things they want. You can't buy what you can't get. That, in short, was the story for the U.S. economy in the third quarter.

title: Taiwanese President Confirms U.S. Troop Deployment on Island
summary: Tsai Ing-wen notes a 'range of cooperation' with the U.S. on defense. WASHINGTON-Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen acknowledged the presence of U.S. troops on the island, describing the deployment as part of broader defense cooperation with the U.S.

title: Economist Explained Politics and Traffic Jams
summary: Anthony Downs, who has died at age 90, studied real-estate markets and clogged roads. He found that voters' 'rational ignorance' drove election campaigns.. Anthony Downs spent most of his career as an economist studying real-estate markets but made a bigger mark in two areas not usually associated with economics: examining the behavior of American voters and explaining why traffic jams couldn't be eliminated in major cities.

title: India's Missile Test Seen as Warning to China After Breakdown in Border Talks
summary: The long-range Agni-5 is country's only missile capable of reaching Beijing. NEW DELHI-An Indian missile test was seen by security experts as a warning shot to China after military talks between the two countries over a contentious border dispute broke down earlier this month.

title: Third Point Doesn't Have the Answer for Shell
summary: Splitting oil from greener business areas wouldn't meaningfully address the oil giant's low stock price or its energy-transition challenge. Third Point is right that Royal Dutch Shell is undervalued, but splitting up the company isn't a great solution.

title: Caterpillar's Profit Doubles on Construction Project Strength
summary: Supply-chain disruptions weigh on growth, chief financial officer says. Caterpillar Inc.'s quarterly profit more than doubled as construction and industrial equipment customers placed new orders in a growing global economy, though supply-chain problems held user sales below the company's expectations.

title: Kyle Rittenhouse Shooting Trial to Focus on Reasonableness, Self-Defense
summary: Jury selection to begin Monday over killings of two protesters and injury of a third in Kenosha, Wis., last year. Prosecutors in the trial of Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager who killed two people and injured a third during unrest in Kenosha, Wis., last year, will have to overcome a longstanding law in Wisconsin that makes it more difficult than in many other states to convict someone who claims self-defense.

title: Regulators Back New Rules to Stop Criminals Using Crypto
summary: New guidelines could spur more crypto firms to check their customers' identities and report suspicious transactions to regulators. Cryptocurrency firms could be forced to take greater steps to combat money laundering under new guidelines released on Thursday by the Financial Action Task Force, an international body that coordinates government policy on illicit finance.

title: Carlyle Earnings Jump as Private-Equity Portfolio Rises
summary: Firm posts record distributable earnings. Carlyle Group Inc. reported a big jump in third-quarter earnings, and the amount of cash it could return to shareholders reached record levels.

title: First Bitcoin. Then GameStop. Now Tiny Tungsten Cubes.
summary: Online investors crave tangible pleasure of holding surprisingly heavy metal blocks; 1.7 times as dense as lead. They bought the bitcoin dip. They took GameStop to the moon. Now the online investor army has a new favorite thing to buy and hold: small tungsten cubes.

title: Luxury House Hunters Raise a Glass to Michigan's Wine Country
summary: Winemakers are setting up shop on Leelanau and Old Mission peninsulas, creating a growing market for high-end real estate, with or without vines. It is the end of October, and Michigan vineyard owner Phillip M. Cifuentes is counting the days.

title: A Nets and Lakers Duel for the NBA Championship? Not So Fast
summary: Brooklyn and Los Angeles are starry picks for a title showdown. Early games-and Kyrie's absence-have shown the road might be rockier than expected.. It's the obvious, glamorous, and honestly-kind of boring preseason pick-for this season's NBA championship.

title: Hertz Posts Quarterly Profit on Travel Rebound
summary: Revenue climbed as leisure travel staged a comeback. Hertz Global Holdings Inc. said it turned a profit for the third quarter as a continued rebound in leisure travel pushed its revenue higher.

title: How Both the Company and Employee Benefit From Higher Pay
summary: Higher pay isn't just a cost. The data shows that the employers that pay the best outperform their peers.. As the economy has lurched forward during the pandemic, many businesses have found themselves forced to increase workers' pay to fill openings-and not everyone is thrilled about it.

title: David Finn, an Aspiring Artist, Prospered in Public Relations
summary: Co-founder of Ruder Finn, who has died at age 100, urged CEOs to worry less about their images and more about improving the world. From childhood, David Finn wanted to be an artist. When it came time to earn a living, he and his best friend, William Ruder, concocted a vague idea about building bridges between industry and the arts.

title: Number Puzzles (Saturday, October 30)
Shiba Inu Coin, Tesla, Ford, Nokia: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Ford shares rose after the car maker lifted its guidance; cryptocurrency Shiba Inu was extending gains. U.S. stocks opened higher amid another wave of earnings from major corporations. Here's what we're watching in Thursday's session.

title: Antidepressant Fluvoxamine Significantly Reduces Covid-19 Hospitalization
summary: Patients who received the low-cost and widely available drug were far less likely to be hospitalized in a clinical trial. A widely available antidepressant holds promise as a treatment for Covid-19, according to a new study.

title: Facebook Faces Official Questions in India Over Policing of Hate Speech
summary: Letter from information technology ministry follows WSJ report that company's own researchers determined its services are awash in inflammatory material. NEW DELHI-India's government has asked Facebook Inc. for details about how it monitors and removes inflammatory content on its platform in the country, according to government officials.

title: China Sticks to Covid-Zero Policies, Despite Rising Pressure to Ease Restrictions
summary: Businesses have called for a plan to end the strict pandemic regime, warning of the increasing economic toll. HONG KONG-A day after a group representing some of the world's biggest banks urged Hong Kong's government to consider more open borders earlier this week, the city said it had no plans to abandon its zero-tolerance approach to Covid-19. Instead, the financial hub said it would tighten measures further.

title: Jobless Claims Fall to New Pandemic Low
summary: Employers are holding on to their workers while struggling to hire more. Worker filings for unemployment benefits declined last week to their lowest level since the coronavirus pandemic began, as employers competed for employees in a tightening labor market.

title: As Children's Covid-19 Vaccine Nears, Some Parents of Kids Under 5 Feel Left Behind
summary: 'It's hard to know we can't get the vaccine,' says a mom of two boys who will be too young to get Pfizer-BioNTech's vaccine when it's authorized for 5- to 11-year-olds. Parents of children ages 5 to 11 will likely soon be able to vaccinate their children against Covid-19. Those with younger children have a longer wait.

title: Budweiser's New Growth Recipe Goes Down Easy
summary: Strong demand for Anheuser-Busch InBev's beer brands protected profits from higher input costs in the third quarter-a good sign as the company tries to cut its debt load. For the first time in a long time, a Budweiser looks more appealing than a Heineken.

title: How Ryan Reynolds Built a Business Empire
summary: Resume Subscription. Don't put that on. That Deadpool mask will offer you zero protection," Ryan Reynolds says, seeing me eye the burgundy-and-black superhero face covering displayed on a credenza behind him. "Actually, that mask will probably give you an STD." His broad smile falls away, replaced with a grave countenance. "No, really," he says, sotto voce. "You will catch something. I did."

title: Frustration Mounts Among NFL Owners Over Washington Football Team Scandal
summary: The controversy surrounding the team, fueled by recent emails that resulted in Jon Gruden's resignation, has prompted some owners to signal concerns with how the situation has been handled. Aftershocks from the National Football League's investigation into workplace misconduct at the Washington Football Team are prompting some team owners to take the rare step of questioning the league's handling of the high-profile investigation.

title: Volkswagen Faces an Even Bumpier Road to EVs Than Detroit
summary: Third-quarter losses from the VW brand are a reminder that the company will be harder to reshape than its U.S. peers. Volkswagen has a way of making investors feel every jolt on its path to electric vehicles.

title: U.S. Bets on Covid-19 Boosters' Efficacy Against a Changing Virus
summary: Federal health officials decide currently formulated vaccines work on original virus and variants. Biden administration health officials are betting the current mix of vaccines and boosters will keep Covid-19 cases trending downward and fend off the contagious Delta variant, though the shots were developed to target the original virus.

title: How the Braves Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Shift
summary: After years rarely deploying the infield shift, Atlanta changed their strategy this season on the way to the World Series. With the Atlanta Braves off to an unexpectedly slow start in May, general manager Alex Anthopoulos met with infield coach Ron Washington to discuss trying a radical new strategy. He didn't know how the conversation would go.

title: Bud Brewer AB InBev Buoyed by Brazil Despite U.S. Weakness
summary: Beer giant says U.S. sales hurt by supply-chain snags, changing tastes. Budweiser brewer Anheuser-Busch InBev SA sold more beer at higher prices in the third quarter, as strong demand in South America helped make up for weakness in the U.S., where drinkers switched away from beer and supply chains were disrupted.

title: Oil's Topsy-Turvy Moment
summary: Depletion of oil storage at Cushing is just one of many market indicators that have flipped since April 2020. Eighteen months after the historic moment when crude oil prices briefly went negative, the oil market has turned upside down.

title: NFT Artist Beeple to Auction a Real-Life Sculpture at Christie's
summary: The sale comes months after Beeple set off a digital art craze by selling a $69 million NFT; the new work is a 7-foot-tall column covered in LED screens. The artist known as Beeple launched the art world's craze for nonfungible tokens by selling one of his digital collages at Christie's for $69 million this spring. Now Beeple has something even more surprising for sale-a real-life sculpture.

title: Can't Buy a PS5? Buy Sony Stock Instead
summary: Chip shortage is temporary. Long term, company's burgeoning entertainment strategy still looks promising. One of the toughest tasks ahead of the holiday season this year is buying a PlayStation 5 for your children. While Sony should be happy about strong demand, the chip shortage also means it won't be able to sell as many as it would like.

title: Global Chip Crisis Hits Auto Makers Hard
summary: Car production collapses in third quarter, but some manufacturers see signs of easing. Continuing disruptions from the Covid-19 pandemic and a worsening global semiconductor shortage hammered the automotive industry in the third quarter as the world's largest car makers reported steep falls in earnings and production and dealers struggled to source models.

title: Evergrande Crisis All But Shuts Bond Market for China's Junk Borrowers
summary: Dollar issuance is likely to struggle into next year, raising refinancing risks. Junk-bond issuance by China's riskier companies has nearly ground to a halt, creating more challenges for the country's real-estate developers that need to roll over more than $40 billion in dollar debt by the end of next year.

title: Global Migration Plummeted During Pandemic, but Labor Shortages Drive Rebound
summary: Industries that rely heavily on migrant workers have been struggling as economies reopen. Migration to rich countries plummeted last year as the Covid-19 pandemic closed businesses and borders, but a rebound is under way as shortages of workers bite and industries that had come to rely heavily on migrant labor over the past two decades reopened.

title: Trendy Baby-Toy Maker Lovevery Gets $800 Million Valuation
summary: Montessori-inspired company raised $100 million in its latest funding round, is on track to IPO in the next two years. Lovevery raised $100 million in its latest funding round, valuing the trendy subscription toy company at more than $800 million and setting it up for an initial public offering in the next two years.

title: What to Know About Buying Carbon Offsets
summary: The purchases help consumers address climate change by seeking to ease the emissions impact from daily activities like travel and shopping. Some consumers might feel eco-guilt about the takeout containers they have been throwing away or the additional packages they have been shipping from Amazon . Offsets are emerging as a way for people to mitigate the effects of shopping, shipping and travel.

title: Brookfield Unit Hires Former Regulator to Expand Life-Insurance Business
summary: Michael McRaith says he would be involved in all aspects of the growth in the U.S. and internationally. Brookfield Asset Management Inc.'s insurance arm has hired a prominent former regulator to help the firm grow its U.S. life-insurance business through acquisitions and other transactions.

title: Fed Leadership Uncertainty Muddies Rate-Policy Outlook
summary: Higher inflation has raised questions in markets over a possible pivot, putting a bigger spotlight on Biden's choices. When Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell steps to the microphone at a news conference next week, he may be unable to answer one of investors' most pressing questions: Will he return for a second four-year term in February?

title: National Cyber Policy Will Disrupt Crime and Instill Hope
summary: A phishing scam can take down critical services on which millions depend. We are organizing a defense.. The Cyberspace Solarium Commission, which assesses U.S. strategy for cybersecurity, warned in its 2020 report that "our country is at risk not only from a catastrophic cyberattack, but from millions of daily intrusions disrupting everything from financial transactions to the inner workings of our electoral systems."

title: Google Needs to Think Old School With Its New Phone
summary: Company heavily touts new in-house chip for Pixel 6, but better carrier distribution would help sales more. Google's new chips aren't going to sell its phones. Its new friends just might.

title: Intelligence Agencies Failed to Predict Rapid Fall of Kabul
summary: Summaries of intelligence reports show how agencies diverged over the strength of the Afghan government and military. WASHINGTON-Leading U.S. intelligence agencies failed to predict the rapid Taliban takeover of Afghanistan prior to the final withdrawal of American troops and instead offered scattershot assessments of the staying power of the Afghan military and government, a review of wide-ranging summaries of classified material by The Wall Street Journal shows.

title: More Tech Whistleblowers Are Expected, Experts Say
summary: Silicon Valley is seeing an increasing number of employees speaking out against practices at their companies, whistleblower attorneys say. More employees of technology companies are coming forward with concerns and information about their workplaces following the disclosure earlier this month of the Facebook Inc. whistleblower's identity, attorneys working on whistleblowing issues said.

title: Shell Aims to Halve Emissions as Activist Calls for Breakup
summary: Oil giant is grappling with competing demands from shareholders. LONDON- Royal Dutch Shell PLC pledged to halve its carbon-dioxide emissions by 2030, a day after activist investor Third Point LLC called for the breakup of the energy giant to improve its environmental and financial performances.

title: Samsung Posts Record Quarterly Revenue From Chip Boom
summary: Quarterly results for the South Korean chip maker, an industry bellwether, exceed expectations. SEOUL- Samsung Electronics Co. reported record quarterly revenue and saw net profit grow by 31% on the back of booming demand for memory chips, though some growth may soon slow as the global component shortage stalls the assembly of various tech products.

title: Democrats Drop Paid Leave From $1.75 Trillion Proposal
summary: White House hosts influential senators as talks continue on social-spending and climate bill; proposed tax on billionaires faces hurdles. WASHINGTON-Democrats abandoned plans to include a paid-leave program in their social spending and climate bill, according to people familiar with the talks, while prospects for a billionaires' levy to help fund the package faded and a potential surtax on wealthy Americans' income gained traction.
